Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: THOMAS WILLIAM BENNETT

Present address: Willow Bunch

Pioneer address:

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1909

Country or place from which you came: India, England

Note to Persons Answering the Pioneer Housing Questionnaire

Since early settlers lived in very different kinds of houses from one time to another, and according to different circumstances, this questionnaire has been divided into three parts:

PART I: The "temporary" shack, sod or log house.
- to include any early dwellings coming under this general description, even though the family may have lived in it for many years.

PART II: The permanent house.
- to include the better house built after living for a time in quarters mentioned above, a permanent home built upon arrival, or the "homestead shack" which may have been added to and continued as a permanent house.

PART III: General.
- including aspects applying to either Part I or Part II of the questionnaire.

Some persons will therefore answer only parts two and three, and others will be able to answer all three parts.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
PIONEER HOUSING

(Drawing by McGregor House)

Please write name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: THOMAS WILLIAM BENNETT
Present address: Willow Bunch
Pioneer address:
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1928
Country or place from which you came: India, England

Note to Persons Answering the Pioneer Housing Questionnaire:

Since early settlers lived in very different kinds of houses from one time to another, and according to different circumstances, this questionnaire has been divided into three parts:

PART I: The "temporary" shack, sod or log house.
- To include any early dwellings existing under this general description, even though the family may have lived in it for many years.

PART II: The permanent house.
- To include the better house built after living for a short time in the shack mentioned above; a permanent house built upon arrival, or the "permanent shack" which may have been added to and continued as a permanent house.

PART III: General.
- Including aspects applying to either Part I or Part II of the questionnaire.

PLEASE COMPLETE THIS QUESTIONNAIRE ON ONE PAGE ONLY, PARTS TWO AND THREE, IF NEEDED.

MAIL TO: Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE No. 9
PART I: THE "TEMPORARY" SHACK, SOD OR LOG HOUSE.

1. What year was this house built? 1909

2. During what years did you live in it? Still living in it.

   How long did you think you might live in it when you built it?

3. What was the location? (township, range, and post office).
   
4. Is it still in existence? Yes

5. What material was it made of? Lumber, and in early years sodded. This was made in 1909.

6. How large was it, and how many rooms did it contain? 40 x 30.

   How were they arranged?

7. Who built it? My father W. Edler.

8. How were the walls finished inside? (e.g., rough boards, mud plaster, painted etc.) Roof Brand.

9. What kind of floors did you have? Lumber.

   What covering did you have on the floor (rushes, linoleum etc.)

10. What expenses did you have connected with the building of the house? This and some following questions answered in accompanying letter.

11. Describe any special problems or unusual happenings connected with its building. Foundation was made 4 ft. so outside measure as extra foundation had to be made when frame work was completed, a storm blew it down which took the rear of sodding it on completion.

12. How many people lived in the house when it was first built? 8 later?

13. What means of heating did you have? Stoves, burning wood and soft coal - we have 250 acres of Poplars.

14. What means of lighting did you use? Coal oil lamps.

15. Was there a cellar? Yes

   Where was the door to the cellar? (in kitchen floor, other place?) In Kitchen floor
PART I: THE TEMPORARY SHACK, SOD OR LOG HOUSE.

1. What year was this house built? 1909
2. During what years did you live in it? 1909-1917
3. How long did you think you might live in it when you built it?
4. What was the location? (township, range, and post office)
5. What material was it made of? (wood, stone, brick, etc.)
6. Is it still in existence? Yes
7. Who built it? My father
8. How were the walls finished inside? (e.g., rough boards, plaster, painted, etc.)
9. What kind of floors did you have? Lumber
10. What expenses did you have connected with the building of the house?

11. Describe any special problems or unusual happenings connected with its building.
12. How many people lived in the house when it was first built?
13. What means of heating did you have?
14. What means of lighting did you use?
15. Was there a cellar? Yes

Was there a door to the cellar? (in kitchen floor, other places)
Dear Jim,

In regard to an interesting event in another

half of our lives, please remember Mr. Roy Lord.

He had been afraid about my father & was very

shy when we met. He was interested, and so did

myself. We met at Leover Park. His call kept me in

for less time than expected.

The date was Dec. 31, 1959 - at 5:30 PM a

storm started to blow off and by 9 PM it was a full

blowout. By a miracle, a simple leaf blew loose

and I met him. He looked around, then surrounded me

with his arms and began to whisper words, so as he

put out the fires - as we were afraid of cold and he

went to the house we were afraid to go back into. We

were so hot we were unable to keep warm. He - we -

were both very hot and very cold, so we decided to try and

decide to a new place. Going on the ship, I heard

off and on Mr. Lord called softly. We were all

very cold and very hot before we fell to our deathbeds.
Dear Jim,

It was an exciting event in our lives.

It had been arranged at my father's place that we were to leave for a hotel in early December.

On the day we were scheduled to arrive, a hurricane hit the area.

Preparing for the hurricane involved strengthening the hotel and ensuring safety measures were in place.

We didn't get very well, the storm was quite overwhelming.

With strong winds, we spent the night in our room watching the storm rage outside.

The next day, after the storm passed, we continued our journey.

This experience taught us the importance of preparation and resilience in the face of natural disasters.

Wishing you all the best in your future adventures.

Sincerely,

Willie Boyd
I dared not tell them the truth which was I did not know alone we were so excited we should not be much longer, and at that time dad looked over the side of the wagon box and was dismayed to see just how bad conditions were he passed some remark well I could not catch and then I called out "we are alright we are HOME" the horses had turned and brought us safely home, and I definitely did not know they had turned.

This was the work of the old time Brave
I dared not tell them the truth which was I did not know what we were or except we should not be much longer, and that time did looked over the side of the wagon box and was damaged to see just how bad condition were the passed some road. Well I could not catch and then I called out "We are all right we are HOME." The horses had heard and brought us safely home, and I definitely did not know they had turned.

This was the word of the old time Brave.
10. The house etc was dark etc. He bought the house a year ago and all equipment and did not decide whether or not.

43. Windows were 2'6" x 2'6" each in depth.

44. A child is 2'6" x 2'6".

My father was manager of a large company in London so I was well traveled. We lived in a large building near the center of town and had large rooms. Building was built at least 50 years ago and was very nice. Please advise if you need any more information. I would be happy to provide any further details.

Possibly two rooms available. Please let me know if needed.
10. The house etc was done over. It brought the owner over $43 and all equipment and did not decline expenses until 26¢.

49. My father was manager for a large company in London, so I would work well handled there and still own a house. Building costs would be low, and I could keep money.

If I knew Leif, any access would be easy.

I would like to own something. If I could find it, I would try.
PART II: THE PERMANENT HOME.

Note: For some persons, this section may include a description of more than one house. If so, you may include a list of houses, showing changes and differences from one house to another. If you have moved since your first permanent house was built, you may describe separately these (or other) houses. If you have lived in several houses, and especially if they have been owned by different people, you may wish to answer questions about each house separately.

16. Give the location (township, range, and post office), of the house (or houses) described in this part of the questionnaire, and the years you lived there. If you lived in other houses besides those you listed here, give their location, and the years you lived in each.

17. Who planned and built the house?

What previous experience did this person (or persons) have in building? Absolutely none.

Where did he get his ideas as to the kind of house to build?

18. What year was it built?

19. How long did it take to build it? (If possible, give approximate dates when started and completed.)

20. Does it still exist?

21. What material was it made of?

22. How large was it? 40 x 30

23. Describe the arrangement of the rooms or, preferably, draw a floor plan of the house. (On a separate sheet, if desired.)

Was there a back shed attached? No

Did you have a front porch? No

Was it glassed in?

24. What kind of foundation was under the house (wooden slats, stone, concrete)?

25. What kind of basement did you have (full size cement basement, dirt cellar, etc.)? No

Where was the door to the basement (kitchen, outside, other room)? No
2.

Page II: THE PERMANENT HOME.

Note: For some persons, this section may include a description of more than one house. If so, you may include a separate entry for each, including changes and differences from one house to another. If such, you may describe your first permanent house on this form. For others, you may choose an example of your houses (or other questionnaire forms will be needed). If you have both owned and rented houses, and especially if they are only about the same age or size, you may wish to answer questions in which you lived, and easily mention those you have not answered in question 16.

In all cases, be sure to make a plain, although not necessarily neat, drawing of the house described in question 16.

16. Give the location (room, town, range, and post office), of the house, or rent (described in this part of the questionnaire, and the year it was built (or occupied). If you lived in other houses before these, you should describe them in other parts of this questionnaire, and the year you moved into each.

17. Who planned and built the house?

18. Where did he get his plans as to the kind of house to build?

19. What year was it built?

20. How long did it take to build it? (If possible, give approximate days, weeks, months, years.)

21. Does it still exist?

22. What material was it made of?

23. How large was it?

24. Describe the arrangement of the rooms or, preferably, draw a floor plan of the house. (On a separate sheet, if desired.)

25. Was there a tack shed attached?

26. Did you have a front porch?

27. Was there a screened or an open veranda?

28. What kind of foundation was under the house (wooden, brick, stone, concrete)?

29. What kind of a basement did you have (full size cement basement, dirt cellar, etc.)?

30. Where was the door to the basement (kitchen, outside, other room)?
26. What insulation was used?
27. Describe the general exterior appearance of the house (square, rectangular, T or L shaped, sharply sloped roof, etc.)
Describe any ornamentation on the exterior of the house (for example, gingerbread, truly carved cornices etc.)

What color was the house, and what color trim was used?

28. How were interior walls finished - (plaster, wood panel, wall-paper etc.)? / /

How were they finished (plaster, beamed, moulded plaster)? /
What kind of wood were the floors made of?
What width board?
Were nails or dovetail used?
Did you have any parquet (patterened inlay) flooring?
Describe the windows as nearly as you can, giving size (length and width), size of panes, height from floor and distance from ceiling.

How were the windows arranged?
Did you have a bay window?
In what room?
Did you have any colored or stained glass windows?
Describe.
Did you have shutters inside or outside?
How were window frames finished inside (painted, varnished)?
outside (painted to contrast with house color)?
Describe your front door (panelling, door, window in door, or around or above).
What kind of hardware was used on the door - (iron, brass etc.)?
Did you have a door knocker?
Describe interior doors - if panelled, type of hardware, or any other special features about them.
Did you have any double doors, French doors or swinging doors?
What material were door handles made of - brass, iron, porcelain (white or colored), glass?
If you had an upstairs, was the stairway open or closed?
If open, what type of baluster and rail was used, and what kind of wood?

PART III: GENERAL.

Note: As you may have more than one answer for questions in this section, please reply to those mentioned in either Part I or Part II, not separately. Use extra sheets if necessary.

46. What did you do to winterize your house (windows, doors, banking (with what?), other means)?

47. What additions were built to the house after its original construction? For what reasons?

48. What animals were in the house at any time? (e.g., dogs, cats or other pets, baby chicks, stock animals or others)

49. As nearly as you can remember, tell what furniture you had in each room in the house (rugs, sofas, chairs, curtains, etc.). If you lived at first in the old house, and later in a larger house, please tell what furniture you had in each place.

How much of this furniture did you bring with you when you came here? How much was it made or purchased?

50. Do you have any pictures of early pieces of furniture, or interior views of your home, which you would be willing to loan or present to the Archives? If requested to do so, would you be willing to co-operate in having pictures taken of any unusual or rare piece of furniture which you might possess?

Certainly.
PART III: GENERAL

Note: As you may have more than one answer for questions in this section, please list them all.

46. What did you do to maintain your house? (e.g., extra sheets, storms, windows, doors, banking, other reasons?)

47. What additions were built to the house after its original construction?

For what reasons?

48. What animals were in the house at any time? (e.g., dogs, cats, other pets, baby animals)

49. As nearly as you can remember, tell what furniture you had in each room in the house, (rugs, chairs, tables, etc.) If you lived in a smaller or old house, and later in a larger house, please list the furniture you had in each place.

How much of this furniture did you bring with you when you came and where was it made or purchased?

How much of it do you still have today?

Describe any items of furniture which were outstanding, or would you have seen strange in the modern home.

How did you get furniture during the first few years (make it, from Eaton's etc.)

50. Do you have any pictures of early pieces of furniture, or interior views of your home, which you would be willing to loan or present to the Archives?

If requested to do so, would you be willing to cooperate in having pictures taken of any unusual or rare piece of furniture which you might possess?
51. Did you or any of your neighbors have looms for weaving, or spinning wheels?  
   A neighbor had a spinning wheel.

52. Tell what furnishings were made for the home, for example, rugs, window curtains, table covers, items of furniture etc.

53. When did you get your first radio?  
   What kind was it?  
   Where did you get it?

54. What use was made of the attic (as a sleeping room? for storage space? for ripening, drying, or storing vegetables?)?  
   Storage space

What windows or means of ventilation were provided in the attic?  
   Two small windows

55. Did you have an indoor toilet?  
   No, I tell away later

56. Did you have any kind of a windbreak (trees, or a windbreak built to protect the house or the door, and from what direction)?  
   No

57. Tell what measures were taken for fire protection, mentioning changes in the form of protection throughout the years, giving dates if possible. (for example, fireguards, lightning rods, fire insurance).  
   Lightning rods, Fire Insurance and Plowed fire guard.

58. Describe any memorable incidents or features connected with any home in which you have lived, not already mentioned in your answers.  
   Answered in accompanying letter
